title: Abusing your team does not make them play better.

replies.body:
Example1 - You're so shit Ezreal, you should just go AFK!
Example2 - Hey if anyone sees two tiny itsy bitsy balls somewhere on the map ping them for Udyr - he seems to have lost his with engages like that!
Example3 - ur shit cunt.


Now, with example one our ezreal went afk, resulting in a 4v5 - obviously we won easily as 4 because we didn't have that feeder ezreal giving the enemy gold! (This is contructive criticism!)
Example two resulted in Udyr making offensive dives in order to show the team he did in fact have balls, resulting in grouping and 5v5 teamfights which we won.
Example three did nothing, the shit player stayed shit - this is useless abuse - please don't do it!

*EDIT* Example 3 was scrublord Skyprus.

Psssshh.
When did I become a scrublord?

I will battle all the toxicity with positivity! 
#playpositive

It's not your job to make your team play better. 
Don't try and control something out of your control.

If you are a better player and know more about the game make yourself self-appointed Shot Caller and make the game winning calls.

always makes me think how the reactions would beif people acted this way irl, miss a shot in basketball, fuck you noob hope u and your family get cancer, other basketball player proceeds to beat the shit out of him lol :P

People were never like this, whether because they were aware of the consequences or because it simply wasn't in their hearts... are people worse because of the lack of consequence or less caring or is it the freedom of expression on the internet bringing out the deep dark hateful side of people?

I know I faced horrible people some times in my life, but most of it was adolescent bullsh-t. Now most conflicts I face or see are for reasons, not bravado or showing off (although that still happens) - but when it comes to the internet every couple of days I see people abusing each other or me, or witness comments about people being downies, comments that they would beat the sh-t out of the other person if they knew where they lived and suggestions to go get cancer etc.

I don't understand. Maybe it's just too easy to type this sh-t and not see the actual effect of your words (hatred) even from other people witnessing you abusing someone else and maybe they need to take time to think between their words or learn to mute people that antagonize or gain the ability to ignore people actively. Maybe it's self-esteem issues and they feel the need to defend themselves from people that are clearly not worth the energy or dignity of their words.

This is what i always ask to people who abuse team.

Derp: [All] OMG Support SO SHIT

Me: [All] Will insults help them get better then?

*Nobody talks for the whole game*
Abuse has to be right, if you come of as a twelvie then it will make them play worse as you're mad.
#playpositive

Coming from you? Someone who is the opposite of consistent, by your logic anyone who gets matched with you should be allowed to talk shit to you.

That player does not exist because everyone and i mean everyone will have a bad game every once in awhile, and do you really think i give a shit what you have to say during game? You can talk shit in game, but guess what ill be climbing up while you will still be stuck in wherever it is you are, not specifically talking about you i'm talking about every player that decides to talk shit to someone who is way above their skill level, the good player simply doesn't care and will just laugh as they climb.

While i was climbing on this smurf account and i was in silver/gold/plat (all equally shit) i had many players talk shit to me calling me bad, look at me now though, they're still stuck in there shitty elo while i'm Diamond and am still climbing.
Didn't try hard enough.

But when we look back and see how are things done:

* Horses run faster when you whip, or sting them with the spurs on the back of your shoes.
* Many, many archaeological architecture wonders were build by slaves driven by overlords while paying their lives during the process.
* Kingdoms in history that lasts the longest in people's hearts are always those with the most dictating ruler who pressured his people with his might.
* Companies with the highest financial potential without using cheap shots and luck are always those that are so stressful they drive workers insane and suicide.
* Finally, wars are won not because of the satisfaction of winning, but the fear of defeat.

No pay no gain, the strong is always right, so they rule. It's not the fault of those leading for being harsh, it's the fault of those who are dragging people down.

Hence there is no wrong in punishing the inferior, we need more people to think like that. Because it DOES WORK.

Pain makes people stronger and achieve greater, it's a Fact, something happy-wishy picnics will never cut for us.

*Meh still, we aren't living in the past nor should we get too serious over some video game, right?*

The flaw in your initial argument is that every relationship described there is one where a particular party has authority.
In a League of Legends game we all enter equal, no leader!
And since no one is a leader no has the right to abuse anyone to get things done, unlike your examples.

Into regards to your "No pain, no gain", 100% agree!
People in LOL give up to easily, you need to fight for every game!
Just because your losing doesn't mean it's a loss!
Work as hard you you can to find the better team fight, place defensive vision, find a pick, create split pressure, out rotate, TAKE SOMETHING BACK FOR EVERYTHING THEY TAKE! 
#neversurrender

I find media distributed information is taken *more seriously* than personal comments, because anonymity opens doorways to unrestricted, unfiltered aspects of life, its ideologies and its attitudes and because of immaturity or simply a persons perspective - can lead to more serious worldly implications as a result of this "raw" data and the feelings that accompany it, however knowing this some people tone down their emotional responses as it leaves openings for attempts at manipulation of this fact of a less filtered ideology or attitude being transcribed; it is a duality in that a more honest comment or more opinionated comment can be taken more seriously - while also be taken less seriously as people have different life experiences and attitudes and may gain more or less than each other in respect to their consideration of other peoples opinions and this spawns radical variations in the status quo of "normality" and barriers between people;

For example - calling someone "a sh*t c*nt" can be a serious tone, or a joke tone - simply a way of notifying them they are not up to scratch in game - or it can be an attack on their personality - as they may take it this way if they consider themselves "excellent" - and can also simply be brushed off as nothing, while the person saying it could be edging to harm the person.

The seriousness of comments on the internet is beyond what I consider public opinion and I think it should be treated more harshly, verbal abuse is sometimes like a disease in that it can trigger anger in others and cause them to become aggressive towards people yet to come in that it can't cause real world effects in most cases so it is transferred onwards as acceptable because it yields no worldly consequence as yet known - furthering punishments for online activities could stop this activity because some people (and this is where real world implications are most common aside from rare cases of people being tracked down and harmed or hacked) - introvert and become self-destructive as a response to abuse, or isolate and I don't think it's fair for anyone - even a ten year old, to call someone a "sh*t c*nt" without a consequence to their ability to do so again - even once because it can have real world implications - most common with cases like this of introversion and it - in many other cases is committed by the victims as they have no way of dealing with a hurtful comment about something that is or is not true in regards to their real-life inputs into the game - other than ignoring it - self-destructing, or lashing out; as is common of society and as such the perpetrators should be dealt with - even if they are simply psychologically and typically responding in like to their experience of something non-impactful or dealing with it in a way that solves their problem (it makes them feel powerful) and eventually the internet - and maybe the world would be filled with people more respectful of each other.

If I punched everyone that had said unkind things, I'd have a lot of blood on my hands - however if I listed every case of abuse in the world in the last year in text - I'd have worked my hands to non-existence and the internet is popular for socializing and playing and is a mini-representation of society - if you say unkind things, you deal with the consequences - just because you are safe from facing the consequences does not mean it is okay to abuse this fact of isolation from reality because like it or not attitudes have real world implications and the government, business and society are quickly catching up and harnessing the internet - with it's simplicity of monitoring - to learn techniques and implement strategies to deal with social problems and the more these habits continue - the more freedoms we will be denied by our "big brothers" and the more likely it will be that while on one side of the coin - social problems will continue with no "reality" faced and what right now is simple to deal with - with harsher penalties could amount to a society unable to deal with even the slightest problems faced and delusional thinking could reign supreme.

I don't want to see a world like this and it's places like this - the free world of the internet that are the beginning of this world - they should be treated as such - by both the administrators - and the users.
